review_text: We had a great time taking a narrated sightseeing river cruise. The staff was very nice and knowledgeable. Everyone enjoyed the tour.
response_from_owner_text:
Thank you for your review. Very nice to hear everyone enjoyed the tour.
Regards,
Cliff

review_text: I went on a cruise about 6 years ago. I enjoyed the scenery and the tour guide and would love to go again if the boat was less crowded. I had to sit on one of the inner benches and then couldn't see well because all the people were standing and were blocking my view and I was shorter than all the people in front of me no matter which way I turned. I would suggest that the guide makes sure the people stay seated and not ruin it for those who had to sit on the inner bench. People on the outer benches have no need to stand. It would have been perfect if less crowded and the people had to stay in their seats.

If you are thinking about having Essex River Cruises and Charters host you event, do yourself a favor and book it now! They hosted our wedding and it couldn't have been more perfect! The customer service you will receive from Alex and Cliff is unmatched. Alex was always helpful and quick to respond to any questions or request I had leading up to the event. The scenery is absolutely beautiful and our guest are still raving about the entire experience! We are amazed how a group of four pulled off the most perfect wedding for 70 people! Thank you from the bottom of our hearts for giving us such an amazing experience that we will NEVER forget! We will be back!

I had a great experience with this company.  The original cruise had to be canceled as there were too few people.  I was followed up with and given the opportunity to reschedule.  The cruise was packed but the views were beautiful.  Wildlife was pointed out and local history told.  The drink I ordered was delicious.

Travel/Food/Lifestyle Influencer: @michaela_romanosmith
Such a fun experience on Essex River Cruises!! We did a brews + chowda themed sunset cruise which was unique and very fun. The ride was smooth, comfortable and the views are fantastic. We saw lots of birds. The chowder was very yummy. Super friendly staff. Also loved that the staff provided info during the tour which made it educational. Highly recommend!!
Great night! Knowledgeable Captain and and a relaxing experience getting to know another corner of the North Shore . Will definitely be back for more tours! Thanks!
We live locally and had never done an Essex cruise.  It was great seeing another side, literally, of the area. Guide have a nice overview.

We had a friend visiting from Michigan and she loves the ocean so this was a great way to sit, relax, and learn some great facts about the area. The Cider and Donuts were a great touch!  Lots of free parking and a little area to hang out and enjoy the cider and donuts.  I brought my own coffee and they didn't mind me bringing it on board.  And the tour guide was excellent. Very knowledgeable about the area and had a great sense of humor as well. I highly recommend it!

Side note:  I do agree with another reviewer about the young children.  It's not engaging enough for a child under 10.  Two hours is a long time to sit still and listen!  If you do bring young children, bring some entertainment and food/snacks for them.
The water is so clear you can see to the bottom. The water is fairly shallow, and fun to kayak in. It's a peaceful place, and all the boats add a nice touch.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: Tons of trails (12 miles!) through woods and wetland. Lots of opportunities for bird watching. Easy-going trails with benches scattered about and an observation tower, featuring a great view over a swamp. 7 dollar fee for non-members - definitely worth it!

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: This is one of my favorite places to go! You can go for a walk, bird watch, feed the birds, and just enjoy the variety of trails and sights to see. I will always recommend this wildlife sanctuary!

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
A beautiful park for a short easy strolling through forest and on riverside walks. A LOT of birds! Well maintained paths. There is an entrance fee, though, if not a member of Mass Audubon.
Winter (without snow) forest & ponds were beautiful, will try other seasons.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
Great place to see birds with nice trails along the coastal marshlands. I only had about an hour, but still got to see a bunch of different birds up close including a hawk. Parts of the trail were submerged after a rainy week, but the views were still amazing.

Admission fee was $7 for adults and $4 for kids.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: Nice area to walk but some of the main trails aren't cleared well and you end up in grassy and muddy areas. My daughter loves it here for the bird watching and feeding the chickadees so we continue to go during spring and summer. The bathrooms are pretty clean and that's a plus.

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
Wonderful place for trails and bird wildlife.
My kids loved it

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text:
BRING BIRD SEED WITH YOU.
Absolute favorite place for a walk. I get to explore so many natural feature and species. Give me a love for birds every time I go here. Special place with long history of many generations of tons of bird species. The birds have been extra friendly here throughout generations. It's hard to find that anywhere else.
Take a big loop. Go on trails with less people. Explore. More chances to have a bird feed of your hand

place_name: Mass Audubon's Ipswich River Wildlife Sanctuary
review_text: Expansive grounds with woods, fields, pond, river and varying terrain. I went with my husband who tires easily and had his walker with a seat. We followed Bradstreet and Drumlin trails. Parts were a little rocky for the wheels of the walker but he managed. We were unable though to take any of the side trails to see some of the better sights due to rougher ground or inclines. There were benches along the trail to rest. We saw many birds and had little ones eating birdseed from our hands. Very peaceful and enjoyable.

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: I attended a plein air event with a friend, hosted by the Cape Ann Plein Air Association. The location was ideal for the demonstration painter who was describing his thought process as he was painting a local historical landmark situated on the grounds of the shipyard.

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: I simply just enjoy small town hidden spots. This is by far the best. Be sure to walk the yard as well.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you for taking the time to write a review. Looking forward to seeing you in the shipyard again

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: If you like history and boats, this place is a hidden gem. A true glimpse into what makes Essex so special.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you for your lovely review! We're delighted you enjoyed the Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum and found a special connection with Essex's unique maritime heritage. Your words mean a lot to us, and we look forward to welcoming you back soon!

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: Cool spot to take a tour and learn some history 7-21

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: We stopped to look around. Jeff came out and made everything we saw come to life Amazing

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: We had a fantastic visit here. First, we received a friendly welcome and an informative tour inside the visitor center/museum. Then we spent a long time exploring the shipyard before heading to the schoolhouse. There, Jim spent a couple of hours- way past closing time- giving us a tour and sharing stories. It's a wonderful place, highly recommended if you love maritime history!
response_from_owner_text: Thank you Peggy! We have new exhibits in the Orientation Center for 2022 and an exciting collaboration with the Smithsonian coming in September. Come see us again soon!

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: This was one of the best museum experiences that my husband and I have had in a long time. Richard Clark, a docent at the museum, gave us a personalized tutorial on shipbuilding that was vivid and informative. Do not miss the school house where Mr. Clark volunteers! Highly recommend!
response_from_owner_text: Marcia, thank you so much for your kind review! We are so lucky to have Rich and our other all star docents to interpret the stories of Essex Shipbuilding to the public! We hope you visit us again in the future!

place_name: The Essex Historical Society and Shipbuilding Museum
review_text: Loved this place! If you like pretty and polish, this may not be your museum, but if you like real and working, you too will love it here. Take your time and discover...all kinds of stuff! There is a lot more here than will at first meet the eye. They build actual wooden boats here too. And by all means don't skip the old schoolhouse annex up the hill and down the block. For some perspective, the day after I visited here, I visited the Maine Maritime Museum in Bath. Of the two, and yes it's a close call, but I prefer Essex. Bath is sprawling, professional, and informative. But Essex...the place itself is an 'exhibit' in it's own right. It makes me smile.
response_from_owner_text: Thank you John! We do pride ourselves on being a place where the lines between exhibit and reality blur. Make sure to come back September/October of this year (2022) to check out our upcoming collaboration with the Smithsonian!

review_text: Such a diverse backdrop for a photo session. And dog friendly too. Follow me @capeannwedding on Facebook and Insta to see more images from Senior portraits and family sessions.
Wonderful place to walk with your dog.
Love this place

We didn't actually plan on coming here. There was hardly any parking at Plum Island, so I looked for public parking, which led us to this little paradise. It's just $5 to enter and park, cash only. There are around eight parking lots throughout the park. Some don't have beach access and are meant for the trails, but there are restrooms at some of the lots.

The first beach access point was pretty crowded and seemed to be the most popular spot. However, if you travel further down, you'll discover various wildlife trails. We stopped and walked the Hellcat Interpretive Trail, which offered natural shade and a clean, well-built boardwalk. Make sure to bring bug spray! We had some in the car thankfully. Then we drove all the way down to the end to Sandy Point. After a certain point, the road transitions from paved to gravel.

The beach was lovely! The water was clear and pristine, and the sand was soft. There were barely any people around. I always keep a beach tent and towels in the back of my car, so we set those up, laid out, and took a nap. I was in awe--how could this whole experience cost only $5?

Sometimes, when things don't work out--like discovering Plum Island has no parking for visitors--you end up somewhere even better <3

This place is very nice. Hard to get there, it takes 17 minutes of driving in wilderness, and the last 5 minutes driving on a not paved road on gravel in clouds of dust from all the other cars in front of you. When you finally get to the parking, you realize, that there are no free spots, cause the lot is extremely small, like for 10 cars only. You have to wait in a huge line, if you are lucky, you get the spot. The beach is beautiful, we came to a low tide. On the other side of the water you can see the edge of the estate of Castle Hill on Crane Estate in Ipswich.

We had a lovely walk here on the sand at low tide. Lots and lots of sand and interesting waves that were coming in perpendicular to the shore rather than parallel something I had never seen before. There is abroad expanse of sand for easy walking but also lots of good rocks for scrambling and plentiful shells if you have kids who enjoy collecting them. Despite the fact that it was 50deg in February, there was almost no one here, probably because it's such a long drive down plum Island to get there.

Located on the southern end of Plum Island, it truly is a gem of a spot. At low tide, ideal for kids playing in tidal pools. Nice Sandy beach. Outhouse at parking area. Small parking lot fills up quickly(lot of empty spots at 9 am Tuesday on July 18, 2023). Buy a season pass at the gate house (annual is $20). They will post signs if Sandy Point is filled, allowing you entrance to the major beach just on the left. Other beaches and parking areas are closed during bird nesting periods. Good nature trails and bird observation platforms. Green heads were a problem for us, even with a wind. Expect your auto to get dusty as the last several miles are packed gravel. Bring an extra bag and feel free to pick-up plastic and other debris that has washed ashore or discarded which is deadly to marine and animal life.
We visited P.I again for a picnic on March 13, 2024 and met an aspiring gymnast as seen here. Two vids taken from an observation tower on the way to Sandy Point.

What a beautiful area and great spot for a bike ride. Got to Sandy Point about 7am having ridden from downtown Newburyport.  The road is gravel the last 3 miles till the end with the last quarter mile being very potholed.  Lots of people bird watching but did not see anyone out on the beach. Would recommend to anyone to visit.

Great beach to spend quality time with family and friends. Parking is a bit tricky; plan ahead and arrive early. Wish I could give this a 5 star, but the staff is rude and unprofessional. One of the rangers at the Sandy Point parking lot told us to park at a spot. We came back to the car about 45 minutes later and gave us a ticket for parking there. The guy denied that he allowed us to park there, but he was the one who redirected us (there was no signs of No Parking either). MAKES NO SENSE!! Be careful.

A little chilly today, but the sun was shining and I had a wonderful walk along the beach.  Then, crossing the road, I enjoyed watching the Hawk's and egrets lifting out of the marsh. I have to admit I spent a bit of time feeling nostalgic, looking across the Sound at Crane Beach. We spent many summer days there in my childhood.
Gorgeous beach!! My first trip to New England coast and it was very enjoyable! So pretty and not too busy. I can't wait to visit again.

Main field is in great shape - really nice dugouts for the players - batting cage - lots of parking - mens and women's bathrooms - little playground - war memorial is nice and while there is a set of bleachers, sitting on the hill in front of the Town Hall feels like a step back in time...
Beautiful scenery. High quality baseball fields. Super clean.
Great place for families with kids
We loved the park and the Fire station tour
Always fresh,  Lee our waitress is awesome
Beautiful park!
Peaceful place to visit. Very short hike to the top of the hill. Dogs are allowed.

The brief walk to the top of the hill is well worth it! The view from the top is nothing less than spectacular. The Great Marsh, entrance to the Essex River, Conomo Point, Hog Island, backside of Crane beach, Castle Hill, dozens of little islands and Ipswich Bay and Cape Ann beyond are all there in front of you.
This is an excellent place to watch the sun rise/set as well as a moon rise/set.

Park on the street and walk 5 minutes up a small incline to a coastal hilltop where you can see panoramic views of Crane Beach and the Essex River estuary. There are rocks you can sit on at the top. Perfect for a picnic.

Pull off the road type parking situation. Brief uphill "climb" - allow 4 minutes. Excellent vista to the Northwest featuring Hog Island, backside of Crane beach and Cape ann beyond. Bountiful golf ball preserve in the woods behind the tower.
A short but steep climb to reach a stone tower and magnificent view of the Essex salt marshes.
The only unobstructed view was of the trees. If you enjoy getting bitten alive by mosquitoes and barely being able to see the beautiful scenery than waste your time.
Well maintained trails; a 10 min  walk gets you a view of the area salt marshes
Very  very short trail
